15 Carers across the Nottingham City and Nottinghamshire County are able to access a number of services to support them 
with their caring role. Available support may depend on whether the cared for is an adult or a child. All carers can access free information and advice and be referred and supported onwards as appropriate.
Other forms of support may include:
• Support groups for carers or to support them with the condition of the person they care for
• Access to health and leisure activities, sometimes at a reduced rate
• One to one support and guidance
• Access to activities for young carers
• A break from the caring role or respite care
• Direct payments for the carer to meet their assessed outcomes

Some people need practical support to do the everyday things t hat most of us take for 
granted. The social care system provides this support for those who need it, to help 
them keep their independence and dignity.  Nottingham City Council Adult Social Care 
Team is responsible for assessing people’s need for social care services in Nottingham 
City.  
When someone contact s us the first step will be to have an assessment to establish i f 
you can receive services. There is a national guidance on this but each authority sets 
its own criteria  on eligibility  for services. If you are assessed and told you meet our 
requirements then the council is obliged by law  to help. If you are not eligible for 
services we will support you by signposting you to other sources of help and support.  
Am I eligible?   
To find out if you are eligible for adult social care services in Nottingham please call the 
Nottingham City Health and Care Point on 0300 300 3333.

In Nottingham, social care users have access to a variety of resources and support services, including advocacy and complaints services. These services are designed to help individuals maintain independence and receive the care they need.

**Key Resources and Support Services:**

- **Advocacy Services:** While specific details about advocacy services are not provided in the documents, Nottingham City Council offers support through various community connections and partnerships. For more information, individuals can contact the Nottingham City Health and Care Point at **0300 300 3333**.

- **Complaints Services:** If you have feedback or need to raise an issue regarding social care services, you can email **betterlivesbetteroutcomes@nottinghamcity.gov.uk**. This is part of the council's strategy to improve services and outcomes for residents.

- **Carers Support:** Carers in Nottingham can access a range of services, including support groups, health and leisure activities, one-to-one guidance, and respite care. The Carers Hub and Young Carers Notts provide social opportunities and activities for carers of all ages. More information can be found at [Carers Hub](https://carershub.carersfederation.co.uk/support-groups/).

- **Information and Advice:** The Adult Social Care Hub provides information and advice on accessing community resources, safeguarding, and financial guidance. Visit the [Adult Social Care Hub](https://healthandsocialcareportal.nottinghamcity.gov.uk/web/portal/pages/home) for more details.

- **Directories of Support:** Ask Lion and Nottshelpyourself are online directories where you can find local support groups and activities. Visit [Ask Lion](www.asklion.co.uk/kb5/nottingham/directory/home.page) and [Nottshelpyourself](www.nottshelpyourself.org.uk/kb5/nottinghamshire/directory/home.page) for more information.

For further assistance or to explore more about the services available, individuals are encouraged to visit the Nottingham City Council's website or contact the relevant departments directly.
